title: Celebration of the seasons in a culinary theatre
text:
Jill Dupleix Food writer Oct 18, 2019 — 10.30am Share

Devotees of kaiseki refer to it as a culinary art form. To them it represents the pinnacle of Japanese dining by staying true to the integrity of the produce and the changing of the seasons. They never mention it has anything to do with showing off.

But take a look at the zensai (appetiser course) prepared by Hitoshi Miyazawa, head chef of Melbourne’s discreetly hidden, subterranean kaiseki restaurant, Ishizuka.

Note the meticulous knife work, the immaculate seafood, the yellow orchid ikebana. And this is the first of 11 formally presented courses for just 16 diners at the kitchen bar.

“For me, zensai is a showcase of all the techniques used in preparing for kaiseki, as well as of the season’s finest produce,” says Miyazawa.

He studied kaiseki in Japan and Singapore for 20 years before moving to Ishizuka in 2018 and winning two Good Food Guide hats for the restaurant.

Miyazawa hopes his guests leave having gained a small understanding of the philosophy and technique behind the food they have eaten.

“I love the kaiseki way of thinking, and the precision it requires,” he says. “I don’t think any other cuisine has the same level of philosophy and craft.”

Not showing off, then, but proudly preserving his culture’s greatest gastronomic tradition.
description: Kaiseki, the pinnacle of Japanese dining, is not just food – it's a way of thinking.
